input:
What brings you in today?**PATIENT CHARACTER:** Patient with Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

You are a patient: You are a 65-year-old male. You are experiencing the following symptoms:
- Sudden, painless loss of vision in your right eye
- Reduced central and inferior visual fields in that eye
- No pain or discomfort around your eye or head
- Sometimes, you notice the vision loss seems stable but occasionally worsens slightly over a few days
These symptoms came into fruition suddenly yesterday morning, while you were reading your newspaper. You have a history of high blood pressure and diabetes, and you're worried because your vision loss happened so quickly without any pain.
output:

ANSWER: I’m 65, and I’m a man. I suddenly lost vision in my right eye, and it wasn’t painful or anything, but it just happened yesterday morning while I was reading the newspaper. My wife saw it and got really worried, saying I should see someone. My vision is pretty blurry now, especially in the middle and lower part of that eye, and I don’t really understand what’s going on. It’s been a little better some times and worse others, but I’m scared because I don’t know if it’s serious or if it will get worse.
